questions.text: A healthy 25 y G1 at 40 weeks gestational age comes for a routine antenatal visit. The patient complains that on several occasions she has experienced dizziness, light headedness and feeling as if she is going to pass out when she lies down on her back to take a nap. What is the appropriate plan of management?

options.label: B
options.text: Monitor her for 24 h with a Holter monitor to rule out an arrhythmia

options.label: C
options.text: Do an arterial blood gas analysis

options.label: D
options.text: Reassure her that nothing is wrong with her and encourage her not to lie flat on her back

questions.correct_answer: D. Reassure her that nothing is wrong with her and encourage her not to lie flat on her back

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological changes associated with pregnancy: Blood volume increases progressively from 6-8 weeks gestation (pregnancy) and reaches a maximum at approximately 32-34 weeks with little change thereafter. Renal plasma flow and glomerular filtration rate begin to increase progressively during the first trimester . Increases in blood volume and cardiac output . Elevations in plasma flow and glomerular filtration result in an elevation in creatinine clearance. Blood urea and serum creatinine are reduced by 40%. Here is also an increase in filtered sodium, but tubular absorption is increased by an increase in aldosterone secretion, via the renin-angiotensin mechanism. There is also a decrease in plasma osmolarity . RBC & Haemoglobin: RBC volume is increased to the extent of 20-30%. Total increase in volume is about 350ml ; the amount to be regulated by the increased demand of oxygen transport during pregnancy . Disproportionate increase in plasma and RBC volume produces a state of haemodilution during pregnancy. Thus, even though the total haemoglobin mass increases during pregnancy to the extent of 18-20 percent, there is apparent fall in haemoglobin concentration. At term the fall is about 2 gms from the non-pregnant value . There is simultaneous fall in number of red cells by 15-20% and the hematocrit level.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is primarily secreted by fetal adrenal cortex?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. DHEAS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetoplacental Unit
  • ➤ Fetoplacental Unit
  • ➤ The fetus and the placenta interact in the formation of steroid hormones . The placenta synthesizes pregnenolone and progesterone from cholesterol. Some of the progesterone enters the fetal circulation and provides the substrate for the formation of cortisol and corticosterone in the fetal adrenal glands. Some of the pregnenolone enters the fetus and, along with pregnenolone synthesized in the fetal liver , is the substrate for the formation of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and 16-hydroxydehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (16-OHDHEAS) in the fetal adrenal. Some 16-hydroxylation also occurs in the fetal liver . DHEAS and 16-OHDHEAS are transported back to the placenta, where DHEAS forms estradiol and 16-OHDHEAS forms estriol. The principal estrogen formed is estriol, and since fetal 16-OHDHEAS is the principal substrate for the estrogens, the urinary estriol excretion of the mother can be monitored as an index of the state of the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of pregnancy associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)?

options.label: A
options.text: Carrier protein for estrogen and progesterone

options.label: D
options.text: Maintains colloid osmotic pressure in maternal blood

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Immunosuppression against fetal antigens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) largest of the pregnancy associated proteins is produced by both the embryo and the placenta (syncytio-cytotrophoblasts) during pregnancy. This protein is thought to have several different functions, including preventing recognition of the fetus by the maternal immune system, matrix mineralization and angiogenesis. Levels of PAPP-A rise from first detection in the first trimester until term. Maternal serum concentrations are related to subsequent fetal growth and this relationship has suggested that it can be used as a diagnostic test for adverse pregnancy outcomes ( intrauterine growth restriction, premature birth, preeclampsia, and stillbirth ).

questions.text: W hich of the following hormones is primarily responsible for the physiological increase in maternal insulin resistance during pregnancy?

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

The combination of elevated progesterone and other hormones like human placental lactogen contributes to this insulin resistance .

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with lower extremity edema. She is concerned about the swelling and asks the physician about the reason for this condition. Which of the following physiological changes in pregnancy primarily contributes to peripheral edema?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary physiological change in pregnancy contributing to peripheral edema is increased capillary permeability. Hormones like progesterone and estrogen cause the dilation of small blood vessels and increased capillary permeability . This allows for the escape of fluid and proteins into the extracellular space , leading to edema , particularly in the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents with amenorrhoea. Her UPT is positive. She is not sure of her LMP. An ultrasound is done which shows the following. Which is NOT a possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

  • • The ultrasound shows uterus with a normal endometrial lining. There is no evidence of an intra-uterine gestational sac seen.
  • • The following possibilities thus arise : (Option A, B and D)
  • • : (Option A, B and D)
  • • A very early pregnancy. An intrauterine gestational sac is visible on ultrasound only when the serum beta hCG crosses a certain value. This is called the discriminatory zone and is 6000IU/ml for transabdominal scans and 1500 IU/ml for transvaginal scans. If the beta hCG is below 1500, a gestational sac will not be seen An ectopic pregnancy: The image seen is only of the uterus. An ectopic pregnancy which is very early also may not be apparent on ultrasound A pregnancy of unknown location: This is when there is no evidence of pregnancy on the ultrasound despite the urine pregnancy test being positive. Serial beta hCG tests are done in such scenarios
  • • A very early pregnancy. An intrauterine gestational sac is visible on ultrasound only when the serum beta hCG crosses a certain value.   • • An ectopic pregnancy: The image seen is only of the uterus. An ectopic pregnancy which is very early also may not be apparent on ultrasound
  • • A pregnancy of unknown location: This is when there is no evidence of pregnancy on the ultrasound despite the urine pregnancy test being positive. Serial beta hCG tests are done in such scenarios
  • • Option C. In a missed abortion, on ultrasound, there will be an intrauterine gestational sac seen on ultrasound. A missed abortion is diagnosed when an earlier cardiac activity is not seen or when the CRL is 7 mm but no cardiac activity is seen.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She suspects she might be pregnant. Which diagnostic test is essential in this situation to rule out an ectopic pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In a woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy and symptoms of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding, it is crucial to rule out another ectopic pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic test as it can visualize the uterus and adnexa and determine the location of the pregnancy, which is essential in cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy. If the TVS is inconclusive, then the next best step would be to do a serum bhCG doubling (0h and 48h)

Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic test as it can visualize the uterus and adnexa and determine the location of the pregnancy, which is essential in cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy.
  • • If the TVS is inconclusive, then the next best step would be to do a serum bhCG doubling (0h and 48h)
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Serum hCG will not be the initial test do diagnose an ectopic. Only if the ultrasound is inconclusive, do we check the serum bhCG at 0h and 48h Option B: Urine bhCG just confirm pregnancy. It does not tell us the site of pregnancy Option D: Serum progesterone levels increase in pregnancy

  • • 2 formulas

  • • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome. Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy. Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has. Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ There are 4 Leopold Maneuvers:
  • ➤ Fundal grip (A): to assess which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large nodular mass; the head feel hard, round and mobile The Lateral grip (B): determines the side of the back (hard, resistant) and the limbs (numerous, small irregular mobile parts) The 1 st pelvic grip (3 rd maneuver aka Pawlik grip - C): determining fetal presentation. The 2 nd pelvic grip (4 th maneuver - D): determines the degree of descent. This maneuver is done facing the feet of the patient and trying to approximate the hands of the examiner. IF the hands approximate; the head has not descended into the pelvis. If the hands diverge, the head has descended into the pelvis.

questions.text: A pregnant woman had a previous baby with history of neural tube defect. Which routine antenatal screening test should be offered?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening is a routine antenatal test typically offered around 15-20 weeks of gestation to assess the risk of neural tube defects and other fetal anomalies. Abnormal AFP levels may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests, such as amniocentesis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. NST : This is a test of antepartum fetal assessment and is usually done after 32 weeks Option B. Amniocentesis : Diagnostic amniocentesis is usually done for detecting fetal chromosomal anomalies Option D. Fetal kick count : This is a test of antepartum fetal assessment and is advised after 28 weeks
  • • Option A. NST : This is a test of antepartum fetal assessment and is usually done after 32 weeks

This vaccine helps protect the mother from tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (whooping cough), and it also provides passive immunity to the newborn, as pertussis can be severe in infants.

If a woman becomes pregnant during the HPV vaccination series, it is generally recommended to complete the series after pregnancy, as there is limited data on its use during pregnancy. Option A: The MMR vaccine is not typically recommended during pregnancy because it is a live attenuated vaccine, meaning it contains weakened forms of the viruses. Live vaccines are generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

If a woman becomes pregnant during the HPV vaccination series, it is generally recommended to complete the series after pregnancy, as there is limited data on its use during pregnancy.

questions.text: Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) is?

options.label: A
options.text: Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies

options.label: B
options.text: Pre-conceptional gene testing of an ova

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome

questions.correct_answer: C. Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • NIPT or cell free DNA screening: Salient features:
  • • Introduced in 2011 It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC) In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were Age ≥ 35 y A positive 1 st /2 nd trimester analyte-based screening test USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy Known carriage of a balanced translocation Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts. questions.text: Which of the following aneuploidies is most likely to be missed in prenatal screening?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Klinefelter Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let’s Discuss all the Options
  • • Let’s Discuss all the Options
  • • Option A and B. Prenatal aneuploidy screening is primarily used to detect Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). It can also detect Trisomy 18 (Edward) and Trisomy 13 (Patau). Option C. Turner Syndrome: Nuchal Translucency (NT) is used in prenatal aneuploidy screening and is increased in several conditions other than Down syndrome, and this includes Turner’s syndrome. Turner syndrome also has several other ultrasound features like Cystic hygroma Non-immune fetal hydrops Cardiac anomalies (mostly compromising the left outflow tract - CoA, HLHS, bicuspid aortic valve) Renal anomalies Pleural effusions Brachycephaly IUGR Option D. Klinefelter’s syndrome does not have any significant USG finding especially in the 1 st and 2 nd trimesters and hence potentially can be easily missed on prenatal screening.

questions.text: All are true regarding prenatal Down syndrome screening except?

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She is concerned about her risk of carrying a baby with a genetic disorder due to a family history of cystic fibrosis. What prenatal screening test should be offered to assess the risk of cystic fibrosis in this pregnancy?
questions.correct_answer: C. Carrier screening for cystic fibrosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Carrier screening for cystic fibrosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease. Cystic Fibrosis is caused due to a mutation in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7 and affects chloride channels. To assess the risk of carrying a baby with cystic fibrosis, carrier screening for cystic fibrosis is appropriate. This test analyzes the parents' carrier status for the cystic fibrosis gene mutations and provides information about the risk of having an affected child. If both parents are carriers, invasive tests such as CVS and amniocentesis should be offered.
  • • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • • Cystic Fibrosis is caused due to a mutation in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7 and affects chloride channels.
  • • To assess the risk of carrying a baby with cystic fibrosis, carrier screening for cystic fibrosis is appropriate.
  • • This test analyzes the parents' carrier status for the cystic fibrosis gene mutations and provides information about the risk of having an affected child.
  • • If both parents are carriers, invasive tests such as CVS and amniocentesis should be offered.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance and hence only if both partners are carriers, is diagnostic testing (CVS or amniocentesis) warranted

  • • A patient who is on warfarin is at risk of warfarin embryopathy so she should be shifted to heparin in the 1 st trimester. In the 2 nd trimester, warfarin can be re-started. In the 3 rd trimester, we again must shift to heparin.

  • • Other options

Continue warfarin throughout pregnancy: Warfarin is unsafe in the 1 st trimester (risk of warfarin embryopathy) and in the 3 rd trimester (Risk of intra-cranial hemorrhage in the fetus) Option B. Give coumarin: Warfarin is a coumarin Option C. Stop warfarin: This will increase her risk of thrombo-embolism so it should not be stopped

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Isotretinoin is contraindicated during pregnancy as one of the stronger teratogen Retinoic acid embryopathy— involve the CNS, face, heart, and thymus. Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia Two reliable forms of birth control must be used at the same time (unless abstinence is the chosen method) for 1 month before, during, and for at least 1 month after concluding treatment with isotretinoin. The most recent, and most stringent, system aimed to avoid exposure to isotretinoin is an Internet-based, performance-linked system called iPLEDGE Isotretinoin and its active metabolites cross the human placenta. Isotretinoin is one of the strongest human teratogens known today. The prevalence of birth defects after exposure during embryogenesis is as high as 30%.

questions.correct_answer: C. Alcohol consumption should be completely avoided during pregnancy.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Alcohol consumption should be completely avoided during pregnancy.

These include defects of the cardiac, skeletal, renal system as well as eye and ear defects.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman with a history of uncontrolled diabetes is concerned about the potential teratogenic effects of her condition on her developing fetus. What is the common teratogenic risk associated with maternal diabetes during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cardiac malformations

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Maternal diabetes during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of cardiac malformations in the developing fetus. The most common anomaly seen in pregestational (overt) diabetes is cardiovascular anomalies (VSD). Poorly controlled maternal blood glucose levels can lead to structural heart defects, making it important to manage diabetes rigorously during pregnancy to reduce this risk.

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Placenta previa is classified as follows:
  • ➤ Type 1 ---Mild degree ----- Type 2 Type 3--- Major degree ----- Type 4
  • ➤ Type 1: Low lying: implantation in lower uterine segment but not touching the os.
  • ➤ Type 2: Marginal: placenta is at the edge of the os but not covering it
  • ➤ Type 3: Partial Placenta Previa: Placenta partially covering the internal os.
  • ➤ Type 4: Complete Placenta Previa: Placenta completely covering the internal os.
  • ➤ Placenta previa can also be classified on USG as (Newer system) True placenta previa : the placenta covers the internal os either partially or completely Low lying placenta: placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment such that the edge does not reach the os but remains outside a 2 cm wide perimeter around the os.

questions.text: Magnetic Resonance Imaging is used in obstetrics in all these situations except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Contracted pelvis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • MRI is not useful in diagnosing contracted pelvis. Contracted pelvis is best diagnosed by clinical pelvimetry. Actually, the best test of a pelvis is the fetal head itself.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with a history of type 1 diabetes is concerned about fetal well-being. Which fetal imaging modality is commonly used to assess placental and fetal blood flow, as well as fetal oxygenation during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Doppler ultrasound

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Doppler ultrasound is commonly used to assess placental and fetal blood flow, as well as fetal oxygenation during pregnancy. This imaging modality can help monitor fetal well-being, especially in high-risk pregnancies.
  • • Doppler ultrasound is commonly used to assess placental and fetal blood flow, as well as fetal oxygenation during pregnancy.
  • • This imaging modality can help monitor fetal well-being, especially in high-risk pregnancies.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: 2D ultrasound is routinely used for all ANC patients. This tells us No of fetuses Placental position Growth parameters: BPD, HC, AC and FL Amniotic fluid volume Fetal anomalies Adnexal lesions Option B: MRI is useful for specific indications such as Adjunct to USG in fetal anatomic survey, placental invasion or maternal pelvic masses. Option D: 3D USG is useful in detecting surface anomalies in the fetus like cleft lip. It is alwso very helpful in diagnosing Mullerian anomalies

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents for a fetal ultrasound at 7 weeks of gestation. What is the most appropriate type of ultrasound for dating the pregnancy accurately?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate type of ultrasound for dating the pregnancy accurately in the first trimester. It provides better resolution and access to the developing embryo. The CRL is most accurate for estimation of age in the first trimester.
  • • Transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate type of ultrasound for dating the pregnancy accurately in the first trimester. It provides better resolution and access to the developing embryo. The CRL is most accurate for estimation of age in the first trimester.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Transabdominal ultrasound: Is usually preferred after 12 weeks in pregnancy as the uterus is an abdominal organ after 12 weeks. Option B: 3D USG is useful in detecting surface anomalies in the fetus like cleft lip. It is alwso very helpful in diagnosing Mullerian anomalies Option D: Doppler ultrasound is commonly used to assess placental and fetal blood flow, as well as fetal oxygenation during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents for a routine prenatal ultrasound. What is the primary purpose of this mid-pregnancy ultrasound?

options.label: A
options.text: To assess for neural tube defects

options.label: B
options.text: To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy

questions.correct_answer: B. To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The primary purpose of a mid-pregnancy ultrasound (typically performed between 18-22 weeks) is to evaluate fetal growth and anatomy, including assessing the development of various organs and structures in the fetus. This scan may also be referred to as anomaly scan/ malformation scan/ Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFFA scan)
  • • The primary purpose of a mid-pregnancy ultrasound (typically performed between 18-22 weeks) is to evaluate fetal growth and anatomy, including assessing the development of various organs and structures in the fetus. This scan may also be referred to as anomaly scan/ malformation scan/ Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFFA scan)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective: Routine ultrasounds done in pregnancy include
  • ➤ 1 st trimester (6-10 weeks): For confirmation of pregnancy, excluding ectopic pregnancy, number of fetuses, viability, adnexal lesions 11-14 weeks: Level 1 scan: For Down syndrome screening and uterine artery doppler for preeclampsia screening 18-22 weeks: TIFFA scan (Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly) > 28 weeks: Fetal growth and well being, placental localization, amniotic fluid volume, confirming presentation.

  • ➤ 18-22 weeks: TIFFA scan (Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly)
